As an important intermediate of organic chemical industry, 2-methylnaphthalene (2-MN) has the application value in the field of medicine and material research. Up to date, the existing researches are aimed at 2-methylnaphthalene saturated hydrogenation and hydrocracking for high value products such as cycloalkanes and BTXs. A series of Ni-based (20 wt.%) catalysts were prepared with different reduction temperatures for the hydrogenation of 2-methylnaphthalene to 6-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene (6-MT) in this study. The results showed that by using NiO/Al2O3-370R, 90.8% conversion of 2-MN and 59.7% yield of desired product (6-MT) can be achieved with optimum reaction conditions of 4 MPa & 340°C, 8 h. Multiple studies including catalyst characterizations, reaction kinetics and density functional theory (DFT) calculation indicates that symbiotic effect of heterostructured Ni-NiO over γ-Al2O3 mainly corresponding to the desired catalytic performance. This study gains fundamental understanding in the effects of valence of Ni-based catalysts in catalytic hydrogenation. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract . Keywords 2-methylnaphthalene Selective hydrogenation Ni-NiO-based catalysts Heterostructured DFT Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Heavy oil produced by refinery and petrochemical processes, which contents heavy molecules, especially multi-ring aromatics, is considered as low quality fuel. The thermal usage has been restricted by stricter environmental regulations [1]. In recent years, the researches of upgrading of heavy oil have been focus on the hydrotreating of multi-ring aromatics, including the reduction of benzene rings for raw materials such as decalins and tetralins in mild condition [1–4], or hydrocracking of ring open to alkyl-benzenes [5–8] and gas [9] in high temperature. The catalytic activity for aromatic rings decreases in the order of ruthenium> platinum> nickel> cobalt [10]. Supported catalysts have been widely reported for aromatics hydrogenation, consisting of the active ingredient sites such as mono-metallic (Ni [2], Pt [11,12], Ru [13]) bi-metallic (NiMo [14,15], NiW [9], CoMo [16]) tri-metallic (NiMoW [17], NiZnMo [18]), and hybrid-metallic(NiP [7,8,19]), with different loading supports such as zeolites (H-ZSM-5 [20], H-beta [21], H-Y [21], H-USY and H-mordenite [22]), C [23], ɣ-Al2O3 [18]. These kind of supported catalysts have significant variations in volume, suitable area surface, the different amount of area acid sites, existing boundary interface, with the strong interaction phenomena between metals and the supports, corresponding to the high activity and selectivity to the aromatic rings [14,15,22]. Meanwhile, a part of these catalysts mentioned above have heterostructure (ig., Ru, Ni, Co-based) [4,24]. Zhu et al. [23] have reported RuNiCo-based catalysts have the high activity for naphthalene hydrogenation and selectivity to decalin. The research indicated that Ru/Ni/NiO/C, Ru/Co/Co3O4/C, Ru/Ni/Ni(OH)2/C and Ru/Co/Co(OH)2/C achieve high activity for aromatic, due to the tri-metallic structure cause positive synergistic effect in catalysts [23,25]. The metal species has the high adsorption capability for H2, and the oxidation species also has the high activity and selectivity for aromatic rings [26]. The structure of -Ni(OH)2-Co(OH)2 active hydrogen species and plays as a bridge for transferring H to activated sites [23,25]. The precious metals can be replaced by transition metal as active site. The heterostructured Ni-NiO-based catalysts are used in other hydrogenation investigated due to the high activity and low cost [27–29]. Song et al. [27] prepared the Ni-NiO precipitation catalysts in hydrogenation of levulinic acid for γ-valerolactone under mild condition. The Ni-NiO catalyst (in reduction temperature of 250°C) has achieved outstanding activity higher than mono NiO (>18 times) and Ni(10 times) species. Chen et al. [28] synthesis the Ni-NiO heterostructured catalysts supported by different type of TiO2 for hydrogenation of furfural to cyclopentanone with different solution. The catalyst reduced in 450°C has the higher activity and selectivity to cyclopentanone in mild condition, than other researches on Ni and Cu metallic supported catalysts [30,31]. However, the NiO/Ni-based catalysts have been rarely selected for aromatics hydrogenation investigated. Additionally, reaction kinetic models have been commonly used for validating experimental results of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons hydrotreating and hydrocracking reactions for researches of catalytic reaction mechanism [32,33]. Qader et al. [32] found that the hydrocracking reactions of polycyclic aromatics follow first-order kinetics with respect to the hydrocarbon concentration at constant hydrogen pressure. Patzer et al. [33] investigated in reaction kinetics model for evaluating the process of 1-methylnaphthalene hydrodealkylated to naphthalene, followed by subsequent hydrogenation to tetralin which, in turn, is hydrogenated to decalin. In this study, catalytic performance and reaction mechanism of heterostructured Ni-NiO-based hydrogenation catalysts for 2-methylnaphthalene have been investigated. The following major works were carried as follow: (a). Heterostructured Ni-NiO species catalysts were selected in 2-Methylnaphthalene selectivity hydrogenation experimental for 6-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene; (b). The heterostructured Ni-NiO and, mono Ni NiO species were identified by morphology study of and valence characterizations analysis, including method of XRD, SEM, TEM, XPS, H2-TPR and BET; (c). Validation and kinetic study of heterostructured Ni-NiO hydrogenation of 2-methylnaphthalene to 6-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene (6-MT) by mathematical model; (d). Theoretical study of Ni-NiO catalyst for hydrogenation mechanism reaction has been investigated, based on density functional theory (DFT). 2 Methodology 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts with Ni loading of 20 wt% were prepared by method of impregnation. The required amount of Ni (NO3)26H2O (Aladdin, China, AR) were dissolved in deionized water. Then, the aqueous solution was added into 8.5 g support of commercial γ-Al2O3 (Rhawn, China, 99.99%, 20 nm) and stirred for 1 h. The sample was evaporated in the oil bath at 65°C and solid bulk was dried at 110°C overnight. The precursor was calcined 2 h at 450°C denoted NiO/Al2O3. NiO/Al2O3 was in situ reduced in reactor under H2 (99.99%) pressure at temperature of 260, 300, 340, 370, 380 and 400°C for 4 h. The reduction catalysts were denoted as NiO/Al2O3-260R, NiO/Al2O3-300R, NiO/Al2O3-340R, NiO/Al2O3-370R, NiO/Al2O3-380R and NiO/Al2O3-400R. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of samples was measured by a Bruker AXS D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu-Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm) at the scanning rate of 4°/min in the degree of 2Ɵ (20–90°) and step of 0.02°. The surface area and pore volume and pore size of the samples of samples were measured with a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ-2 instrument by N2 adsorption-desorption at −196°C. The samples were heated under the vacuum 150°C for 2 h to eliminate the volatile species before measured. The morphology and crystal lattice of samples images were obtained by Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM: JSM-7500F, Japan) and Transmission electron microscopy (TEM: FEI TalosF200S, Portland) projection at the acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The temperature programmed reduction (TPR) experiments for reduced catalysts at different temperature were performed on the chemisorption apparatus (TP-5080, Tianjin, China). The catalysts were analyzed in the condition of H2/Ar(5 vol%) and in temperature range of 100°C to 1000°C at the heating rate of 10°C / min. The samples were pretreated in the Ar flow before the experiments. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy of samples were measured by Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi (XPS) surface analysis instrument. The accurate binding energies (±0.1 eV) were calibrated by using the peak of C1s (284.8 eV). The elemental composition of calcined sample was analyzed by Axios X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF, Panalytical Company of the Netherlands) 2.3 Assessment of catalytic performance The hydrogenation of 2-methylnaphthalene (2-MN) was performance in the batch reactor (YanZheng Apparatus, YZRJ-250ml). Before each experiment, 1 g catalysts, 10 g 2-methylnaphthalene and 100 ml solvent of cyclohexane (Aladdin, China, AR) were added into batch reactor. After 3 times purges with H2 under the pressure of 3 MPa, the batch reactor was injected pressure of 4 MPa in room temperature then heated to the pre-set temperature with heating rate of 5°C min−1. The stirring speed was selected at 800 rpm in each experiment. The batch was cooled down to the room temperature at each end of reaction. The products of liquid phase and used catalysts were separated by organic membrane. The liquid products were analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) (Agilent 7890B) and HP-5 capillary column (0.25 μm × 0.32 mm × 30 m) and FID detector was selected. The temperature of oven was kept in 50°C in 3 min initially. Then, the temperature increased to 160°C at the rate of 5°C/min and remained for 10 min. The gas phase was analyzed by micro-GC and equipped with both FID and TCD detectors. The conversion of 2-methylnaphthalene ( C 2 − M N ), yield and selectivity (Yi and Si) of 6- methyl -1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene(6-MT), 2-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene (2-MT) and 2-methyldecaline (cis and trans isomers) are calculation in Eqs. (1)–(3), respectively. (1) C 2 − MN = n f − n p n f × 100 % (2) Y i = n i n f × 100 % (3) S i = n i n f − n p × 100 % In Eqs. (1)–(3), nf and np represent the initial fraction of feed and product molar fraction of 2-MN, respectively. ni represents the molar fraction of 6-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene (6-MT), 2-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene (2-MT) or 2-methyldecaline (2-MD), respectively. Due to the low amount of coke (mcoke /mf < 0.1 wt%) and gas product phase (ngas products/ nconsumption H2< 0.1 mol%) after the each experimental, the total carbon balance of feed and liquid phase product can be approximated to 100%. 2.4 Kinetics model calculation Based on the experimental product distribution of the previous studies of 2-MN catalytic hydrogenation mechanism [18,34], a lump model of the reaction system has been established as shown in Figs. 1 and 2 . It is assumed the main reactions during the 2-MN hydrogenation process consisted of 4 pairs of reversible reactions. The mass balance equations that are required to evaluate the apparent reaction rate constants of the model (k1-k8) were established by additional assumptions: (1) The external diffusion is considered to be eliminated by the high stirring rate of 800 rpm [35], since this stirring speed ensures the negligible external mass transfer resistance . (2) Internal mass transfer limitation can be ignored for NiO/Al2O3-370R with average particle size of 20um (Fig. 6) [36]. Based on above assumptions, material balances for each of the considered component were developed as follow: (4) d C 2 − M N d t = − k 1 P H 2 2 C 2 − MN − k 2 P H 2 2 C 2 − MN + k 5 P H 2 2 C 6 − MT + k 6 P H 2 2 C 2 − MT (5) d c H 2 d t = − k 1 P H 2 2 C 2 − MN − k 2 P H 2 2 C 2 − MN + k 5 P H 2 2 C 6 − MT + k 6 P H 2 2 C 2 − MT − k 3 P H 2 3 C 6 − MT − k 4 P H 2 3 C 2 − MT + k 7 P H 2 3 C 2 − MD + k 8 P H 2 3 C 2 − MD (6) d 6 − M T d t = k 1 P H 2 2 C 2 − MN − k 5 P H 2 2 C 6 − MT − k 3 P H 2 3 C 6 − MT + k 7 P H 2 3 C 2 − MD (7) d 2 − M T d t = k 2 P H 2 2 C 2 − MN − k 6 P H 2 2 C 2 − MT − k 4 P H 2 3 C 2 − MT + k 8 P H 2 3 C 2 − MD (8) d 2 − M D d t = k 3 P H 2 2 C 6 − MT + k 4 P H 2 2 C 2 − MT − k 7 P H 2 3 C 2 − MD − k 8 P H 2 3 C 2 − MD Where k i is the kinetic constant in standard Arrhenius form in the ith reaction: (9) k i = A i e ( − E A , i RT ) 2.5 Theoretical simulations For calculating adsorption energy of H2, H and 2-MN over Ni (1 1 1) and NiO (1 1 1), spin polarized DFT was calculated by using Materials Studio 2017 [37,38]. The exchange and correlation effects were described through the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) by the exchange-correlation functional of Perdew and Wang (PW 91) [39,40]. Energy cutoff of 400 eV and mesh of 3 × 3 × 1 k-point was used for the electron wave function was expanded using plane waves with an and was used. The vacuum spacing of all models was greater than 15 Å. For the calculating adsorption energy of hydrogen and hydrogen atom, conjugate gradient algorithm was using to relax forces of geometries, until all atoms of unconstrained were less than 0.01 eV/Å. The surfaces of Ni (1 1 1) and NiO (1 1 1) were described by a four layers slab and a (3 × 3) supercell [41,42]. For calculation adsorption energy of 2-methylnaphthalene, 5 × 4 supercell of four layers surfaces of Ni (1 1 1) and NiO (1 1 1) were constructed and the 2 layers bottom atoms were fixed. Structures were relaxed until the atoms were unconstrained smaller than 0.05 eV/Å. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The volumetric valence difference between NiO/Al2O3 sample and NiO/Al2O3 with partial in situ reduction samples has been be identified by XRD patterns and H2-TPR profiles shown in Fig. 3 . Furthermore, the average particle sizes of Ni and NiO species were shown in Table S1, which have been obtain by Multimodal fit of and calculated of Scherrer Equation. The increasingly reduction of NiO (NiO: JCPDS-47-1049) to Ni (Ni: JCPDS-04-0850) species is clearly illustrated as increasing of reduction temperature, the significant characteristic peaks (37.1˚ 45.9˚ 66.9˚) of γ-Al2O3, corresponding to PDF#74-2206 [43]. The peaks of NiO (1 1 1), NiO (2 0 0) and NiO (2 2 0) can be identified in the NiO/Al2O3-260R pattern clearly. Also, the weak peak of Ni (1 1 1) can be identified, this indicates that a few ratio of Ni species formatted in the temperature of 260°C. The significance peaks of Ni (1 1 1) and Ni (2 0 0) emerged in NiO/Al2O3-340R pattern. Moreover, for reduction temperature of 370°C, the peaks of Ni (1 1 1), Ni (2 0 0) and Ni (2 2 0) became more distinct. Furthermore, the calculated particle size of Ni species is roughly the same (Table S1). The diffraction of crystal plane of Ni (1 1 1) Ni (2 0 0) and Ni (2 2 0) became more significant and shaper than NiO species. The peaks of Ni (1 1 1), Ni (2 0 0) and Ni (2 2 0) can be observed obviously in NiO/Al2O3-380R patterns. Meanwhile, the weak peak of NiO (2 2 0) was also found. Also for the NiO/Al2O3-400R, the peaks of Ni (1 1 1), Ni (2 0 0) and Ni (2 2 0) can be identified clearly, this indicates the NiO species can be basically reduced in such temperature with particle size is roughly unchanged (Table S1) [44]. Chemical adsorption and reduction properties of catalyst samples, (Fig. 3(b) H2-TPR), further explain valence variety of with different reduction temperatures. For NiO/Al2O3, the single reduction peak was found at 557°C. However, it can be seen that the peak shifts to right (574°C) in the NiO/Al2O3-260R and NiO/Al2O3-340R profiles. The H2-TPR profiles of NiO/Al2O3-370R, NiO/Al2O3-380R and NiO/Al2O3-400R contain secondary peaks in temperatures of 289°C, 215°C and 163°C, respectively, and this indicates weak chemical adsorption over Ni0 active site [45]. It can be seen the high temperature peaks shift to the right (NiO/Al2O3-370R and NiO/Al2O3-400R), this can be explained as increased ratio of Ni0 and chemical adsorption of hydrogen on stronger Ni active sites [46]. Moreover, the adsorbing peaks of NiO/Al2O3-400R at low (159°C), and high temperature (657°C) became weaker. This indicates the bulk of NiO species has been substantially reduced to Ni0 which is consistent to XRD patterns. The XPS spectrogram of Ni 2p of NiO/Al2O3-380R, NiO/Al2O3-370R, NiO/Al2O3-340R and NiO/Al2O3-260R are shown in Fig. 4 (a) to illustrate the Ni-NiO formed on surface, and the dependency of Ni and NiO species ratio on temperature is semi-quantitatived by area of peak in Fig.4(b) and Table S2. The peaks at 852.7 and 870.2 eV corresponding to metallic Ni0 2p3/2 and Ni0 2p1/2 can be observed. Also, the typical peaks of Ni2+ 2p3/2 and Ni2+ 2p1/2 located at 860.2 and 873.5 eV. The satellite peaks at 862.1 and 880.2 eV [47,48]. Additionally, the peaks at 530.3 eV and 531.6 eV corresponding to the O-Ni 1s and O-Al 1s can be observed [49]. These of typical peaks can be observed in the samples of NiO/Al2O3-260R, NiO/Al2O3-340R, NiO/Al2O3-370R and NiO/Al2O3-380R. It indicates both Ni and NiO existed in the catalysts samples, which are in accordance with the previous researches [47,48]. Also, the percentage of Ni-NiO obtained by XPS spectrogram was increased (Fig. 4(b)). As from XPS spectrum of NiO/Al2O3-260R, it can be seen that the peak area of Ni2+ is much larger than the Ni0 area, corresponding to Ni2+ and Ni0 in form of 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively. The semi-quantitatived ratio of Ni2+ is approximately to 90.3% (Table S2). It can be identified the area of Ni0 is enlarged in NiO/Al2O3-340R spectrum. The area ratio of Ni in NiO/Al2O3-370R is about 40.9% (Fig. 4(b) and Table S2), indicates that higher temperature caused a deeper reduction of catalyst samples. Majority of NiO/Al2O3-380R peak area was by Ni0 2p spectrum in ratio of 70.5% (Table S2). Same phenomenon can be further observed with presence of the peaks of O-Ni(530.3 eV) and O-Al(531.6 eV) in the samples of NiO/Al2O3-260R, NiO/Al2O3-340R, NiO/Al2O3-370R and NiO/Al2O3-380R (Fig. 2(b)), which is in consistency to previous research [49]. From the Fig. 4(c), it can be seen as the reduction temperature increased from 260 to 340°C, the area of O-Ni 1s decreases slightly. It can be observed a sharp decreasing in peak area with reduction temperature increases to 370°C. Also, the area of O-Ni is almost negligible in the sample of NiO/Al2O3-380R. This indicates that O-Al becomes the main constituent in catalyst sample [49]. Moreover, the peak of Al 2p is almost unchanged, which indicates that the mutual effects between ɣ-Al2O3 support and loaded Ni are roughly the same on surface of samples (Fig. 4(d)). The XPS spectrum in Fig. 4 showed the catalysts sample with different reduction temperature, further supporting the valence changes of Ni species of XRD results and H2-TPR profiles. The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore size distributions of the reduction catalysts in the different temperatures are appeared in Fig. 5 . The catalyst composition and calculated textural properties including BET surface areas, total pore volume and average pore size are shown in Table 1 . Catalyst samples whole corresponded to type IV, and exhibited evident H3 hysteresis loops in P/ P0 region of 0.5-1.0. This phenomenon caused by properties of support of γ-Al2O3 and reduction treating, that attributed to aggregation of platy shaped particles or pore expansion [50]. As shown in Table 1, BET surface areas (SBET) of catalyst samples were in small fluctuations in the range of 134 ± 8 m2 g−1. This indicates that the superior activity of the Ni-NiO catalysts are not trivially related to the difference of surface area [51]. As shown in Fig. 5 (b) and Table 1, the average pore size of catalysts are in range of 12.5–14.5 nm, suggesting that all catalyst samples contained mesopore [52]. Microscopic analysis is wildly occupied in characterization of Ni-based catalysts. It can provide useful information about the morphology structure of surface and interior of solid samples. The results of microscopic analysis NiO/Al2O3-370R is shown in Figs. 6 and 7 . As shown in Fig. 6(a), the morphology of the γ-Al2O3 supported catalysts is in form of 2D sheet, which is suitable for adsorption of plane shaped 2-methylnaphthalene [53]. Also, the TEM image (Fig. 6(b)) illustrates the γ-Al2O3 was in shape of stick and the Ni-based particle were fully dispersed. In addition, the particle distribution of Ni-based particle has been fitted by Gaussian function, with the corresponding size with median 6.25±0.24 nm. As the high-resolution (HRTEM) shown in Fig. 6(c), NiO (1 1 1), NiO (2 0 0), Ni(1 1 1) and Al2O3 (4 0 0) species can be distinguished, with corresponding lattice fringes in distance of 0.242 nm, 0.213 nm, 0.206 nm and 0.197 nm, respectively. Also, the formation of NiO (1 1 1)/ Ni(1 1 1) lattice fringe with perpendicular direction(encircled area with dashed curve) confirms the formation of heterostructured Ni-NiO [54]. Also, the appropriate distance between the lattice fringes of NiO (1 1 1), Ni (1 1 1) and γ-Al2O3 (4 0 0) indicates the existence of Ni-NiO heterostructure over Al2O3 [27]. Moreover, from Fig. 6(c), two different morphologies can be observed in the Ni-NiO heterostructure distinguished by NiO (1 1 1) and Ni (1 1 1) lattice fringes. In the left part of Fig. 6(c), the distance between the NiO (1 1 1) and Ni (1 1 1) is relatively close (1 <nm), and the overlapping of these two forms is significant. However, in the right part, it can be seen clearly that the distribution of lattice fringes of Ni (1 1 1) and NiO (1 1 1) are segregate. Also, the boundary of adhesive particles becomes more obvious and the NiO (2 0 0) species can be distinguished. A high-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) image with sub-angstrom resolution further confirmed that uniform of Ni-NiO had been formed (Fig. 7), and the corresponding energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) maps showed that the Ni atoms partly distributed over Al [24], which gave further confirmation of supported on NiO/Al2O3-370R (Fig. 7a) [55]. The characterization results of XRD (Fig. 3(a)), XPS (Fig. 4), H2-TPR (Fig. 3(b)), HRTEM (Fig. 6) confirm the existence of Ni, NiO and Ni-NiO heterostructure. Besides, the Ni- NiO heterostructure might result in the cooperation effects for catalytic performance of catalysts. 3.2 Product distributions and effects of catalyst reduction temperature The product yields and effects of catalysts reduction temperature on hydrogenation performance of 2-MN are shown in Fig. 8 . The liquid phase after the reaction mainly consisted of 6-MT, 2-MT, 2-MD and unreacted 2-MN, while the gas phase were found to be the mixture of volatile solvent (cyclohexane) and excessive H2 and gas products (nconsumption H2/ngas products<0.1 mol%) . Fig. 8(a) shows the difference in conversion rate of 2-MN catalyst samples in different TOS. In general, catalysts with low reduction temperature (260–300°C) have higher conversion rate than that with higher reduction temperature (370–400°C). While, the optimum reduction temperature of catalyst is found to be 370°C, as NiO/Al2O3-370R has highest conversion rate of 2-MN at the end of stage (TOS= 8 h). These phenomena indicate that the performance of Ni, NiO and Ni-NiO supported catalysts are clearly different in hydrogenation process. Moreover, as TOS= 6-8 h, the 2-MN conversion rate become flatten at the end of stage (TOS=8 h) except for NiO/Al2O3-370R and NiO/Al2O3-370R, which indicates the hydrogenation system approaches to equilibrium in forward and backward reactions. Also, performance including conversion profile, yield and selectivity of desire products at 8 h TOS, 340°C with different catalysts is shown in Fig. 8(b). The NiO/Al2O3 have the desired 2-MT conversion (80.7%) and yield of 6-MT (51.6%). It indicates that active ingredient of NiO species has high activity for aromatic rings, as the previous reported in hydrogenation process [26]. It is observed that NiO/Al2O3-260R exhibited high activity in conversion of 2-MN (88.6%) and yield of 6-MT (55.7%). NiO/Al2O3-370R performed the high activity and achieved the highest yield of 6-MN (59.7%). However, as NiO/Al2O3-380R, NiO/Al2O3-400R performance shown, the higher temperature (380- 400°C) caused in sharp decreased of catalytic activity, and low conversion of 2-MN and yield of 6-MT. Integrating the catalytic performance with catalysts characteristic data (XRD patterns, H2-TPR profiles & XPS spectrums), the Ni and NiO species were co-existence in NiO/Al2O3-260R, NiO/Al2O3-340R and NiO/Al2O3-370R have the desired conversion file as TOS, and higher yield and selectivity of products. Also, Ni and NiO species can be identified in the used NiO/Al2O3-370R as TOS in 2-8 h. Meanwhile, the percentage of Ni is 40.9% on the surface initial and remained at approximately 50% as TOS=2-8 h. It indicates that Ni and NiO species can be co-existence during the 2-MN hydrogenation process and achieved higher activity than mono NiO species (NiO/Al2O3). NiO/Al2O3-380R achieved lower activity (2-MN conversion of 6-MT yield of 58.4%) significantly, corresponding to the majority of Ni species. Also, the higher reduction temperature (400°C) lead to existence of mono Ni species, corresponding to the lowest activity of all catalysts samples (2-MN conversion of 46.4%) [53]. Moreover, the comparison of catalytic performance between NiO/Al2O3-400R and NiO/Al2O3 indicated that NiO species showed more activity than Ni species for aromatic rings in 2-MN hydrogenation process [26]. In terms of 6-MT selectivity, the performance of (NiO/Al2O3) or Ni (NiO/Al2O3-400R) catalyst was superior to that with co-existence of Ni-NiO (NiO/Al2O3-370R). Also, NiO/Al2O3-370R achieved the higher selectivity for 6-MT (65.7%) among the Ni-NiO species catalysts). It is probably caused by the appropriate ratio of Ni/NiO (Figs. 4 and S3) as TOS=0-8 h, lead to high adsorption of 2-MN molecular and high desorption of 6-MN molecular under the appropriate hydrogenation condition [56]. However, the selectivity variety between the different catalysts samples is slightly (61.0–66.5%). In comparison to the reported catalysts, from Table 2 it can be seen Ni/Mo-Al-MCM-41 and NiO/Al2O3-370R possessed higher activity in terms of 6-MT yield, while the Ni/Mo-Al-MCM-4 [15] had higher productivity of 6-MT (100%) and MTs (70%). However, the catalyst/feed mass ratio(mcat.:m2-MN) was approximately 3 times higher than NiO/Al2O3-370R, which meant the prepared NiO/Al2O3-370R catalyst in this study had remarkably higher capacity of generating 6-MT with the same TOS, as well as lower cost of catalyst per unit mass of desired product(6-MT). Additionally, the reaction condition of NiO/Al2O3-370Re was considerably moderated than Ni/Mo-Al-MCM-4 [15]. This indicates the energy consumption and hazard would be reduced significantly. Furthermore, in these study, the reaction temperature was kept below 400°C for avoiding to 2-MN hydrocracking [15]. 3.3 Reaction kinetic model for NiO/Al2O3-370R catalytic hydrogenation of 2-MN For further investigate in catalytic performance of Ni-NiO species, a mathematical model has been developed to simulate NiO/Al2O3-370R catalytic performance in hydrogenation process of 2-MN, including product distributions and catalyst activity changes with reaction time (TOS) and reaction temperature. The mathematical model parameters were predicted by simulated results with experimental data by regression method. As shown in Figs. S1 and S2, respectively, the predicted model of relative content of 2-MT and 6-MT was validated by comparing mathematic model with corresponding experimental results. X-axis is for prediction by model while y-axis is for the data of experiment. It can be clearly observed that the model predictions of product are in close agreement with corresponding experimental data at different operating temperatures. Also, as statistical data shown in Table S3, the prediction of model and experimental data have strong statistical correlation. Therefore, the developed mathematical model is qualified of in-depth correlation of behavior of NiO/Al2O3-370R in 2-MN hydrogenation process. The pre-exponential factors (A) and activation energy (E) values of parameters evaluated by developed model of 2-MN to 6-MT are given in Table 3 . 8 chemical reactions involved in catalytic hydrogenation reaction model that can be classified into two main categories: reactions belong to low (E< 80 kJ mol−1) and high (E> 80 kJ mol−1) class activation energy. R1 and R2 identify to low activation energy reactions, indicates that the conversion of 2-MN to 6-MT, 2-MT can occur at any reaction temperatures (320–360°C). Also, the activation energy of R1 is lower than R2, indicates that conversion of 2-MN to 6-MT (R2) is more easily take place in lower temperature (320°C). R3- R8 belong to high class indicates that conversion of 2-MD enhances, caused by higher temperature (350–360°C). Meanwhile, the reverse reaction of 2-MN conversion to 2-MT and 6-MT can be significant. R4 and R5 are higher than other reactions (E > 250 kJ mol−1), indicates that the rate of direct formation of 2-MD can nearly be negligible at low temperature (320°C), but increasing significantly as the reaction time increase in high temperature of 360°C. The model predicted and experimentally measured product distributions effected by reaction temperature and reaction were shown in Fig. 9 a–e, for five reaction temperatures from 320°C to 360°C, respectively. It can be seen, as the reaction time increased, the fraction of 6-MT, 2-MT and 2-MD from the hydrogenation reaction increased with former time, while the fraction of 2-MN continuously decreased. It can be also found that the opportune reaction time and temperature for 90.8% conversion of 2-MN was in 8 h at 340°C. By taking into account of the 6-MT yield, 59.7% was highest at the preferred reaction temperature of 340°C. Well, due to reverse conversion enhanced significantly at the high temperature of 360°C, the conversion of 2-MN decrease to 81.8%. Also, the yield of 6-MT decreased to 53.1%. 3.4 Theoretical calculations based on DFT for reactant adsorption on surfaces of Ni (1 1 1) and NiO (1 1 1) As can be seen in the XRD pattern (Figs. 3(a) and S1) and XPS spectrogram (Figs. 4 and S2), the NiO/Al2O3-370R contained the appropriate rate of Ni and NiO percentage in both fresh and used catalyst after the 2-MN hydrogenation process (TOS= 0-8 h). It indicates that the presence of heterostructured Ni-NiO (Fig. 6) and slightly variety of Ni-NiO heterostructured border [58]. Meanwhile, the NiO/Al2O3-370R achieved the high performance, in terms of high activity and productivity of 6-MT. These indicate the existence of Ni-NiO heterostructured in NiO/Al2O3-370R during the 2-MN hydrogenation reaction. The molecular model based on characteristic results has been constructed to explaine the high hydrogenation performance of NiO/Al2O3-370R during the 2-MN process. Meanwhile, the adsorption energy of H2, H atom and 2-MN on Ni (1 1 1) and NiO (1 1 1), based on primary first principle has been calculated. The calculation results of the lowest energy structure of H2, H atom and 2-MN adsorbed on Ni (1 1 1) and NiO (1 1 1) are illustrated (Fig. 10 ) and corresponding data obtained by geometry optimization are summarized (Table 4 ). The adsorption energy of H2 and H atom, respectively, on Ni (1 1 1) is higher than NiO (1 1 1) are good agreement with previous reported [59,60]. Comparing with the relationship between the Ni (1 1 1) and 2-MN, NiO (1 1 1) displayed much stronger interaction with 2-MN (-0.93 eV), corresponding to shorter bond length of structure (C-Ni: 1.65). Therefore, 2-MN prefers to adsorbed on NiO (1 1 1) over Ni (1 1 1). The proportion of Ni and NiO species of NiO/Al2O3-370R was found to be approximately 50% (XPS semi-quantitatived) during the reaction (Fig. S3). Therefore, the area of the Ni (1 1 1) and NiO (1 1 1) for H2, H atom and 2-MN is approximately the same. The reverse of 2-MN to 6-MT can undergo a reaction pathway over co-existence surface of Ni (1 1 1) and NiO (1 1 1). As shown in Fig. 11 , H2 and 2-MN preferentially adsorbed on Ni (1 1 1) and NiO (1 1 1), respectively. Due to the adsorption of H2 on Ni (1 1 1), the H-H bond may dissociate into H atoms. Because of the Ni (1 1 1) surface defect, H atoms may probably overflow to NiO (1 1 1). Meanwhile, the adsorbed 2-MN on NiO (1 1 1) can contact H atoms to produce 6-MT in neighboring regions. As different active sites are involved in 2-MN hydrogenation over Ni-NiO species, the apparent kinetic of 2-MN to 6-MT does not conflict to Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism. The DFT calculation results, together with experimental results and characteristic observations can supply a explain of species of Ni, NiO and Ni-NiO cooperation in hydrogenation of 2-MN to 6-MT. 4 Conclusions In this research, Ni-NiO-based heterostructured catalyst with γ- Al2O3 as the support was prepared, for selective hydrogenation of 2-methylnaphthalene to 6-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene. Catalyst characterization, hydrogenation performance, reaction kinetics and theoretical calculations based on DFT were carried out for investigating of the reaction mechanism. The conclusions of this study are drawn as follow: (a) NiO/Al2O3-370R exhibited the high performance in hydrogenation of 2-MN for 6-MN. 2-MN conversion of 90.8% and 6-MT yield of 59.7% were achieved under the condition of 340°C, 4 MPa initial pressure and reaction time of 8 h. (b) Characterization analysis such as XRD, H2-TPR, XPS, HRTEM, indicated that heterostructured Ni-NiO could significant enhance the catalytic performance of 2-MN. NiO/Al2O3-370R, with heterostructured Ni-NiO (the proportions of Ni and NiO species is approximately 50% during the reaction), shown the higher cooperation function for hydrogenation of 2-MN for 6-MT. (c) Kinetic parameters show that the conversion of 2-MN to 6-MT (R1) belong to low activation energy (E < 80 kJ mol−1). The high temperature (360°C) should be avoid, due to higher temperature enhances conversion of 2-MD (R3, R4), meanwhile the reverse reaction of conversion to 2-MT and 6-MT can be significant (R5, R6). Moreover, reaction kinetics indicates that the appropriate reaction conditions including reaction temperature (340°C), reaction time (8 h) are critical to yield of 6-MT. (d) Further investigated through theoretical calculations based on DFT, the adsorption energy of 2-MN on the surface of NiO (1 1 1) is higher than Ni (1 1 1). The mechanism is probably illustrated: H2 and 2-MN preferentially adsorbed on Ni (1 1 1) and NiO (1 1 1), respectively. Meanwhile, hydrogen atoms exothermic dissociation into atomic hydrogen, and may probably overflow to NiO (1 1 1) surface. The adsorbed 2-MN on NiO (1 1 1) can react with adsorbed H to produce 6-MT in neighboring regions. coredata.dc:description: As an important intermediate of organic chemical industry, 2-methylnaphthalene (2-MN) has the application value in the field of medicine and material research. Up to date, the existing researches are aimed at 2-methylnaphthalene saturated hydrogenation and hydrocracking for high value products such as cycloalkanes and BTXs. A series of Ni-based (20 wt.%) catalysts were prepared with different reduction temperatures for the hydrogenation of 2-methylnaphthalene to 6-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene (6-MT) in this study. The results showed that by using NiO/Al2O3-370R, 90.8% conversion of 2-MN and 59.7% yield of desired product (6-MT) can be achieved with optimum reaction conditions of 4 MPa & 340°C, 8 h. Multiple studies including catalyst characterizations, reaction kinetics and density functional theory (DFT) calculation indicates that symbiotic effect of heterostructured Ni-NiO over γ-Al2O3 mainly corresponding to the desired catalytic performance. This study gains fundamental understanding in the effects of valence of Ni-based catalysts in catalytic hydrogenation.
coredata.dc:title: Selective hydrogenation of 2-methylnaphthalene by heterostructured Ni-NiO-based catalysts for 6-methyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene
